Yeah, when I was making the piece I was wondering if I was being too blatant. But what I found out was that in general, people didn't know exactly what they were looking at - that I wasn't blatant enough. The viewers mostly got the general idea, but there is a lot of "is that a....(body part X)?" The shaft like shape you see as a penis on the bottom left (middle bottom) is supposed to be a female leg of sorts. And actually the whole piece is supposed to be female parts (except for a small male, distorted figure in the center of the painting) but I can easily understand people seeing all sorts of things in this painting. "fairly clear outline of the body of a woman from boob to bum" - this was my intention, but a lot of people do not notice this. Cool that you saw it. "amalgamation of mouth and tongue" - In my mind, it is a person sucking on a lip attached to a face with a large mouth - what appears to be a large hole is the inside of the mouth. While these particular parts of the painting are fun to talk about, it's not important that the viewer's interpretations match perfectly with what I intended - in fact, if this happened then I wouldn't have done a very good job at making the painting mysterious. As long as the over all feel of the painting is maintained, then I feel like I've done something right. Thank you for explaining some of your thoughts on the painting.

I chose all of these cards using the same process (except Preacher). I looked at the card text only and specifically avoided looking at the original art so I wouldn't be influenced by it. Because of this, I had to avoided cards that I already knew the art for (which is a lot). So my enthusiasm for making the art was based on the name, functionality, and flavor of the card. One time, I read the description of Ruric Thar, The Unbowed and I was getting psyched up to do a piece based on his card text. Then at an FNM I was looking through somebodies trading binder and saw Ruric! It was a double whammy. Now that I had seen it, I couldn't UNSEE it. But also, the art for him is AWESOME. It's probably for the best I didn't try because I don't think I could top it, let alone match it. I actually ended up meeting this artist and told him the story, pretty funny.

My process for all of these (except Preacher) was to only read the text of the cards, but NOT look at the art. I knew that I would be too influenced by the original art if I saw it. This is the closest way I have found to matching the art orders that WotC gives the artists and hence the process the artists go through. It was always exciting to FINALLY see the original card art after I was done with my version. One thing I noticed was that the original always seemed more, for lack of a better word, "Magical". Mine were usually a little less creative than the MtG world requires and it's something that needs to be addressed if I give it another go. And yes, in most cases (if not all) just starting a new piece is better than trying to fix something older up.
